title: Glory to Hong Kong
text:
"Glory to Hong Kong" is a <a href="March%20%28music%29">march</a> that was composed and written by a musician under the pseudonym "Thomas dgx yhl", with the contribution of a group of <a href="Hongkongers">Hongkonger</a> <a href="netizen">netizen</a>s from the <a href="Internet%20forum">online forum</a> <a href="LIHKG">LIHKG</a> during the <a href="2019%E2%80%932020%20Hong%20Kong%20protests">2019–2020 Hong Kong protests</a>. It was initially written in Cantonese and was eventually developed into various language versions. It has been adopted as the <a href="anthem">anthem</a> of these protests, with some considering it the "<a href="national%20anthem">national anthem</a> of Hong Kong".
Since widespread protests in Hong Kong erupted in early June 2019, various songs that symbolise democracy, such as "<a href="Do%20You%20Hear%20the%20People%20Sing%3F">Do You Hear The People Sing</a>" from "<a href="Les%20Mis%C3%A9rables%20%28musical%29">Les Misérables</a>", have been sung by protesters on different occasions as their anthems. "Glory to Hong Kong", according to the composer, was created "to boost protesters' <a href="morale">morale</a> and unite people". Since the song's publication, it has been sung at most demonstrations. There are also numerous versions in English and other languages.
Background.
Thomas, a music composer and Cantonese-language lyricist, first posted an instrumental version of "Glory to Hong Kong" and its lyrics on 26 August 2019 to <a href="LIHKG">LIHKG</a>, an online forum where pro-democracy <a href="Hongkongers">Hongkongers</a> exchange views. After receiving suggestions from the forum users, he modified the lyrics, including the incorporation of the phrase "<a href="Liberate%20Hong%20Kong%2C%20the%20revolution%20of%20our%20times">Liberate Hong Kong; revolution of our times</a>" (), a motto at the protests. The song's music video, comprising scenes from demonstrations, was uploaded to YouTube on 31 August 2019. The song went viral within a few days across various social media, followed by the emergence of versions in English and <a href="%23Other%20languages">other languages</a>. An orchestral music video with <a href="SATB">SATB</a> chorus was uploaded to YouTube on 11 September 2019, reaching 1.5 million views within a week. Hong Kong protesters previously sung "<a href="Do%20You%20Hear%20the%20People%20Sing%3F">Do You Hear the People Sing?</a>" and "<a href="Sing%20Hallelujah%20to%20the%20Lord">Sing Hallelujah to the Lord</a>" as protest anthems, before adopting "Glory to Hong Kong" as their main anthem.
In an interview with "<a href="Time%20%28magazine%29">Time</a>" magazine, the author-composer said: "Music is a tool for unity, I really felt like we needed a song to unite us and boost our morale. The message to listeners is that despite the unhappiness and uncertainty of our time, Hong Kong people will not surrender." In an interview with "<a href="Stand%20News">Stand News</a>", the composer explained his motivation to compose a new protest song for Hong Kong in place of songs commonly sung during protests such as "<a href="Boundless%20Oceans%2C%20Vast%20Skies">Boundless Oceans, Vast Skies</a>" and "Glory Days", two songs by Hong Kong band <a href="Beyond%20%28band%29">Beyond</a>, describing the songs as "not unpleasant to listen to", but that their rhythm was somewhat out of place with the atmosphere during protests. The composer said he was predominantly a <a href="pop%20rock">pop rock</a> artist, noting that a classical-style production like "Glory to Hong Kong" was a personal first. Inspired by "<a href="God%20Save%20the%20Queen">God Save the Queen</a>", "<a href="The%20Star-Spangled%20Banner">The Star-Spangled Banner</a>", the <a href="national%20anthem%20of%20Russia">national anthem of Russia</a>, the "<a href="Battle%20Hymn%20of%20the%20Republic">Battle Hymn of the Republic</a>" and "<a href="Gloria%20%28Vivaldi%29">Gloria in Excelsis Deo</a>" by <a href="Antonio%20Vivaldi">Antonio Vivaldi</a>, he spent two months composing the song's melody working backwards from the line "" ("Glory to Hong Kong", or loosely translated as "May people reign, proud and free").
The song was observed by to have similar motives to <a href="Roman%20Tam">Roman Tam</a>'s "<a href="Below%20the%20Lion%20Rock%20%28song%29">Below the Lion Rock</a>", a Cantopop song highly regarded among Hong Kongers in association with the sense of <a href="Lion%20Rock%20Spirit">the region's common spirit</a>.
Origin of the title.
The word "glory" () in the song title consists of the Chinese characters for honour () and brilliance (). The term has been used in poems by <a href="Li%20Bai">Li Bai</a> and a prose by <a href="Lu%20Xun">Lu Xun</a>, in addition to being a common term used by Christians. The composer noted that he was irreligious, and described the last sentence "Glory be to Hong Kong" () as his twofold wish: that Hong Kong can regain its glory in the future, and that Hongkongers are willing to dedicate their pride and triumphs to the city.
While this is largely an antiquated term in modern Chinese, it is still in common usage in modern Vietnamese (), Japanese (; "eikō") and Korean ().
Lyrics.
"Glory to Hong Kong" comprises four <a href="stanza">stanza</a>s of lyrics in Cantonese. The author states that he prioritised the meaning of the lyrics over the rhyming of lines, and explains the meaning of each stanza as follows:
The first <a href="%3Awikt%3A%20stanza">stanza</a> solemnly describes the suppression and deprivation of fundamental human rights, such as democracy, <a href="liberty">liberty</a> and <a href="justice">justice</a>.
The second stanza describes the <a href="2019%E2%80%932020%20Hong%20Kong%20protests">anti-ELAB movement</a>, where the people stand up to injustice even though blood is shed. The solemness follows that in the first stanza.
The third stanza describes the perseverance of Hong Kong people in darkness and despair. It is performed with slightly less solemn character.
The final stanza, with the most recognisable <a href="motto">motto</a> "Liberate Hong Kong; revolution of our times" incorporated in the <a href="lyrics">lyrics</a>, envisages that the city will regain its glory and honour. It expresses hope for the future, ending the song with excitement.
Other languages.
Various versions of English lyrics have appeared online. Shek Ga-mak, a Hong Kong <a href="expatriate">expatriate</a> in Germany, released German lyrics for the song on 11 September 2019. Japanese lyrics for the song were also released by an <a href="Anonymity">anonymous</a> Japanese person on 18 September 2019. Members of Action Free Hong Kong Montreal performed a French version written by <a href="netizen">netizen</a> assuming pseudonym "Montreal Guy", which was uploaded to YouTube on 26 September 2019. "Pícnic per la República" released and sung a <a href="Catalan%20language">Catalan</a> version on 24 October 2019 in front of the Chinese Consulate of Barcelona. A Taiwanese version was premiered by the indie band "The Chairman" during a solidarity concert in Taipei on 17 November 2019.
Public use.
The song has been sung on numerous occasions by citizens in the public all over the city. 200 people participated in a <a href="sit-in">sit-in</a> at <a href="Prince%20Edward%20station">Prince Edward station</a> on 6 September 2019, requesting <a href="MTR">MTR</a> to hand over footage of the <a href="2019%20Prince%20Edward%20station%20attack">attacks on passengers conducted by police on 31 August</a>; in addition to chanting slogans, the protesters sang this anthem and "Do You Hear the People Sing?". A few hundred people sang the song together at <a href="Cityplaza">Cityplaza</a> on 9 September. On 10 September, <a href="Hong%20Kong%20national%20football%20team">Hong Kong</a> football supporters sang the song at a match for the first time during a <a href="2022%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%E2%80%93%20AFC%20Second%20Round">FIFA World Cup qualification</a> match against <a href="Iran%20national%20football%20team">Iran</a>, booing the Chinese anthem. On the same night, the song was again publicly sung by large groups at more than a dozen shopping malls across Hong Kong at 8:31 pm, a reference to both the police attacks on 31 August and the <a href="2014%20NPCSC%20Decision%20on%20Hong%20Kong">2014 NPCSC Decision on Hong Kong</a> which was declared on 31 August 2014. On 11 September, around 100 people sang the song together in a memorial meeting for a suicide victim held at <a href="Ka%20Shing%20Court">Ka Shing Court</a> in <a href="Fanling">Fanling</a>. Around 500 students from 10 secondary schools in <a href="Kwun%20Tong%20District">Kwun Tong District</a>, <a href="Tseung%20Kwan%20O">Tseung Kwan O</a> and <a href="Kowloon%20City%20District">Kowloon City District</a> organised a <a href="Human%20chain%20%28politics%29">human chain</a>, in which they sang the song. Around 1000 people sang the song in <a href="New%20Town%20Plaza">New Town Plaza</a> together that night, with crowds of people singing the song in other shopping malls around Hong Kong as well.
Reception.
Robyn Dixon and Marcus Yam of "<a href="Los%20Angeles%20Times">Los Angeles Times</a>" described "Glory to Hong Kong" as having "a more indigenous, electric, unifying effect" when compared to songs that were previously used at the protests. The march's <a href="Cantonese">Cantonese</a> lyrics, in particular, affirms a sense of a collective cultural identity which is at the heart of the conflict. The lyrics evokes a sense of pride and belonging to Hong Kongers who struggle for identity after the 1997 hand-over to China. The <a href="hymn">hymn</a>-like composition was also seen as "supremely approachable" to the populace who were accustomed to the Christian music tradition introduced by the region's <a href="Education%20in%20Hong%20Kong%23History">British and missionary-influenced educational system</a>.
The Chinese edition of "<a href="Deutsche%20Welle">Deutsche Welle</a>" named "Glory to Hong Kong" the "anthem" of the Hong Kong protests. The Chinese edition of <a href="Voice%20of%20America">Voice of America</a> describes the lyrics of the song as reflecting the heartfelt views of protestors. Taiwanese newspaper "<a href="Liberty%20Times">Liberty Times</a>" described the song as "the military march of protesters" (), singing their anxiety towards Hong Kong's political situation, as well as an "unrelenting revolutionary spirit". Describing the song, <a href="Chinese%20Television%20System">Chinese Television System</a> News noted that the song had "peaceful vocals coupled with scenes of bloody conflicts between Hong Kong Police and the people" and that by creating "Glory to Hong Kong", Hongkongers recorded their "history of struggling for democracy and freedom". , a professor of politics and public administration at the <a href="Chinese%20University%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Chinese University of Hong Kong</a> noted that the song's melody and lyrics resonated with many people and united protesters, leading to many people developing great "attachment" to the song. Former <a href="President%20of%20the%20Legislative%20Council%20of%20Hong%20Kong">President of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong</a> <a href="Jasper%20Tsang">Jasper Tsang</a> praised the song as a high-quality technical production, believing it to be produced by professional musicians. He said that the song shows that the government's efforts at promotion have been weak.
"<a href="Wen%20Wei%20Po">Wen Wei Po</a>", a state-owned newspaper controlled by the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Liaison%20Office">Hong Kong Liaison Office</a>, published an article on its front page on 12 September, criticising the song as the anthem for <a href="Hong%20Kong%20independence">Hong Kong independence</a>, and that the lyrics idealise violence. The title of the article, "" may be translated as "Independence song brainwashes, touting independence as the route [for Hong Kong]", though "independence" may be treated as a pun for "poison" in this context due to its Chinese pronunciation. published an article in "<a href="Ming%20Pao">Ming Pao</a>" on 13 September entitled "The brainwashing song that trumpets Hong Kong independence" (), in which she describes the "elegant lyrics" of the song as "advocating hate", and that "seeds of violence and hatred have been sown into the brainwashing song, causing people to inadvertently dance to its <a href="Baton%20%28conducting%29">baton</a> and commit bad behaviour".
The song has been described as the unofficial anthem of Hong Kong, and some protesters stated they felt that "Glory to Hong Kong" should replace the Chinese national anthem "<a href="March%20of%20the%20Volunteers">March of the Volunteers</a>" as the national anthem of Hong Kong; to which, the composer insisted that the song can only be a <a href="protest%20song">protest song</a>: "There is no nation. How can there be a national anthem?" On the other hand, an opinion piece by Brian C. Thompson, a Chinese University of Hong Kong senior lecturer, for "<a href="The%20Globe%20and%20Mail">The Globe and Mail</a>" argues that despite only a "few" minority of the protesters are <a href="separatism">demanding for a separate state</a>, the march is used as a thematic anthem representing the collective demands of the Hong Kong people – which are also considered "a nation [...]. A state may be home to multiple nations..." – therefore the march can still be regarded as "national" in nature.
There were also slight criticism with how the march was made in terms of – its lyrics were seen in a professional sense as "clumsy" and its melodic range not only "too wide for most amateur singers" to which its lyrics' <a href="Cantonese%23Tones">spoken tones</a> are not synched by.
The song has gained a huge popularity in Ukraine, as for the result of the song's name and slogan was inspired by the traditional Ukrainian slogan "Слава Україні! Героям слава!" ("<a href="Glory%20to%20Ukraine">Glory to Ukraine</a>! Glory to the heroes!") The Hong Kong's slogan version was also used by Ukrainian protesters in solidarity with the Hong Kong protesters.
Controversies.
, a host of <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>-based Chinese-language radio station <a href="CJVB">CJVB</a>, received complaints from local Chinese residents after playing "Glory to Hong Kong" live on radio. She rejected rumours that she was suspended, whilst refusing to comment further.
"<a href="Apple%20Daily">Apple Daily</a>" published an article on 15 September, quoting <a href="RTHK">RTHK</a> staff who claimed to have received a notice from their managers on 12 September which told them not to play the song outside of news and <a href="phone-in">phone-in</a> programmes for the needs of "news broadcasting" due to its ties with Hong Kong independence. The article also quoted that the song should be deleted from recordings of shows where previously played, due to an alleged violation of the RTHK Charter which states that RTHK should fulfil the purpose of "engendering a sense of citizenship and national identity through programmes that contribute to the understanding of [Hong Kong's] community and nation". After holding meetings with employees, Director of Broadcasting instead said that the song was to be avoided due to its controversial nature. Responding to the newspaper's enquiry, Ng Man-yee of RTHK responded that its management has not banned "Glory to Hong Kong", has not deleted the song from its database, and as far as she knows, has not discouraged playing the song.
Lai Rifu, a <a href="Weiquan">Weiquan</a> dissident, was arrested by <a href="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a> police for <a href="picking%20quarrels%20and%20provoking%20trouble">picking quarrels and provoking trouble</a> on 16 September. On 13 September, Lai had shared a video to <a href="WeChat">WeChat</a> and Facebook, which showed scenery around his home town and used the song as its background music, with the caption "This is my homeland, I want her to be free!" On 18 September, around 20 pro-democracy activists, including <a href="Civic%20Party">Civic Party</a> legislator <a href="Kwok%20Ka-ki">Kwok Ka-ki</a>, <a href="Civil%20Human%20Rights%20Front">Civil Human Rights Front</a> convener <a href="Jimmy%20Sham">Jimmy Sham</a> and members of the <a href="League%20of%20Social%20Democrats">League of Social Democrats</a> rallied to the Hong Kong Liaison Office, demanding the release of Lai. The activists chanted slogans and sang the song outside the Liaison Office's entrance.
Copyright infringement by secondary creations.
On 12 September, a video titled "Glory to Hong Kong (Police Version MV)" () appeared on YouTube. It uses the original song and lyrics in audio, paired with scenes of <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Police%20Force">Hong Kong Police</a> using <a href="tear%20gas">tear gas</a> and other <a href="crowd%20control">crowd-control</a> weapons on protesters. On the screen, however, the lyrics "Revolution of our Times" were replaced with "Mission of the Police". Since being uploaded, this MV had received criticism from <a href="netizen">netizen</a>s which were removed later that night. Timelapse photographer Francis So condemned the MV on his Facebook page, stating that the timelapse of the night view of Hong Kong near the end of the video infringes his copyright. <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Cable%20Television">Cable TV</a> also made a statement regarding clips from <a href="I-CABLE%20News%20Channel%20%28Hong%20Kong%29">i-CABLE News</a> used in the video, saying that they would retain the right to pursue all <a href="copyright%20infringement">copyright infringement</a>s.
Following this incident, another video titled "May Truth be Bestowed Upon Hong Kong" () appeared. It used the instrumentals of "Glory to Hong Kong", but lyrics were rewritten by someone under the pseudonym "a person who loves Hong Kong" () to praise the Hong Kong Police Force and to fight against "rioters". <a href="Lin%20Xi">Lin Xi</a> made a remark stating that the use of instrumentals from the original "did not give a sense of violation, and was like a match made in heaven". He opined that the problem was the definition of "rioters, whether they were those who abused their power to arrest and beat up people or the powerless force that was attempting to fight back". This MV was reuploaded to <a href="Sina%20Weibo">Sina Weibo</a> by various Chinese communist official organisations, such as the "<a href="People%27s%20Daily">People's Daily</a>" and the <a href="Communist%20Youth%20League%20of%20China">Communist Youth League</a>.
On 28 September, the fifth anniversary of the <a href="Umbrella%20Movement">Umbrella Movement</a>, a YouTube channel named "Channel Me" uploaded a video titled "Peace Upon Hong Kong" (). It was a video spoof of the orchestral MV of "Glory to Hong Kong" by Black Blorchestra. It was also re-uploaded to other social media, including <a href="Junius%20Ho">Junius Ho</a>'s Facebook page. All uploads of this song were later blocked by <a href="Content%20ID%20%28system%29">Content ID</a> claims by <a href="Denise%20Ho">Denise Ho</a>'s label Goomusic.
Following the enactment of <a href="Hong%20Kong%20national%20security%20law">Hong Kong national security law</a>, some phrases in this song (particularly references to protest chant <a href="liberate%20Hong%20Kong%2C%20the%20revolution%20of%20our%20times">liberate Hong Kong, the revolution of our times</a>) were deemed "separatist and subversive" by the government, and thus illegal under Hong Kong law.
